subject: Re: [junit] testing interfaces only and dependecy injection in test cases
msgSnippet: ... When faced with this situation in the past I separated the tests into white box and black box parts. The black box parts I implemented as assertions
messageBody:
2008/4/23 jensnz <jensnz@...>:
> Sorry if this is a question that has already been discussed (it
> probably has because its so obvious, but I could not find anything
> about it). I want to write test cases that reference interfaces only
> as I want to publish them as part of a spec â€“ they are to define the
> semantics of classes.

When faced with this situation in the past I separated the tests into
"white box" and "black box" parts.

The black box parts I implemented as assertions about the behaviour
implied by the interface.

The white box parts I implemented as unit tests that put a known
implementation into a known (significant) state and then passed it to
a black-box assertion.

E.g. I might have two implementations of List: LinkedList and ArrayList.

I would have assertions that I can add an element onto the end of the
list and retrieve the last element, adding an element increases the
size by one, etc. etc..

I would have tests for the implementations that exercised specific
internal states. For example, for an ArrayList I would have tests
that added an element to an empty list, to a list that has a full
array that needs to be expanded, etc. Those tests would call the
assertions. Something like:

import static ListAssert.assertAddingAnElementIncreasesTheSizeByOne;

...

@Test public void
addingAnElementIncreasesTheSizeByOne() {
assertAddingAnElementIncreasesTheSizeByOne(new ArrayList());

List listAtCapacity = new ArrayList(4);
listAtCapacity.addAll(Arrays.asList(1,2,3,4));
assertAddingAnElementIncreasesTheSizeByOne(listAtCapacity);
}

If those tests got too large (as above), I'd break them into separate
test methods.

--Nat
